clinical_study.brief_title: Study of Low-Dose Total Skin Electron Beam Therapy in Mycosis Fungoides
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Open-Label Study on Low-Dose Total Skin Electron Beam Therapy in Mycosis Fungoides

brief_summary.textblock: The purpise of this study was to determine the effect of low-dose (4 Gy) total skin electron beam therapy as a second-line treatment of stage IB-II mycosis fungoides.

detailed_description.textblock: Current treatment modalities are usually not curative and having treatment options suitable for the long-term control therefore essential. Electron beam therapy is generally applied to the skin in total doses of 30-36 Gy over a 8-10 week period.Due to the potential risk of toxicity including bone marrow supression, no more than 2-3 courses in a life time are generally recommended. In the current study we explored the possibility of using lower radiation doses for total skin electron beam therapy for long-term disease control.

clinical_study.why_stopped: The study was discontinued after the first 10 patients because of discouraging results.

intervention.intervention_name: Low-dose total skin electron beam therapy (4 Gy)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- histologically confirmed mycosis fungoides stage I-II with failure to obtain full remission after standard PUVA treatment or relapse within 4 months of PUVA treatment
Exclusion Criteria:
- under 18 years, pregnancy, other somatic diseases with a life expentancy under 1/2 years, psycological disorder preventing the patient to understand the information and cooperate in the treatment
